text:
﻿Sony Script
Hook:

Sony has just been sued for $7.9 billion, and 
might have to pay out over 9 million players.

The reason is quite unsettling, but it gets 
worse. They’ve been caught deleting TV shows,

movies, and games people were told they owned 
“forever”. These aren’t isolated incidents,

they come from Sony’s new strategy. The 
consequences of which could be massive.

Chapter 1: The Sony Lawsuit
Setup

In 2022, a lawsuit was filed against 
Sony by Alex Neill, the CEO and founder

of “consumer voice”. She’s been fighting 
and advocating for consumers for years,

and this was her biggest fight 
yet. So what was her claim?

The official lawsuit website states that
“Sony has a near monopoly on the sale of

digital games and add-on content through 
its control of the PlayStation Store.

Sony uses this dominance to enforce strict terms 
and conditions on game developers and publishers.

These terms allow Sony to set the price of 
digital games and in-game content and charge a

30% commission on every purchase.
(source)

As a result, most content for PlayStation games 
are incredibly expensive. There’s been a massive

rise in the cost of digital content, 
along with “deluxe editions” of games.

Hold on, can’t a company charge what they want? 
Can’t they set their own prices? Most of the time,

yes. But for such a giant company like 
Sony, it’s a bit more complicated.

Tension
The PlayStation

store is a marketplace for video games, one of 
the biggest in the world. Sony owns the platform,

putting them in a position of power similar 
to the iOS app store and Google play store.

When a company has this much power, they can 
abuse it, which hurts the consumer. That’s why

there are laws to prevent this from happening.
In Chapter 2 of the 1998 Competition Act,

it states that a business in a “dominant position” 
cannot abuse their position. For example they

cannot limit production, charge different 
prices to different customers, and most of all:

charge excessively high prices.
(Source. Show chapter 2,

or section 18 “abuse of dominant position”).
This is a cornerstone of the lawsuit.

Neill and her lawyers argued that Sony 
has abused its dominant position. That

it has been “unfairly charging its UK 
customers too much for digital games

and in-game content purchased 
through the PlayStation Store.”

“Games are now designed to incentivize 
players to spend as much money as possible

(including children).”
But there was a problem.

None of this would matter, if 
the lawsuit wasn’t approved.

Class action lawsuits in the UK need to be 
approved by the Competition Appeal Tribunal, and

if the judges weren’t convinced that Playstation 
was harming consumers, it would be thrown out.

Sony could continue overcharging players, and 
it would all be for nothing. Many actually

expected the suit would be thrown out, 
but then, something unexpected happened.

Resolution / Payoff
To Sony’s dismay,

in November 2023, the UK Competition 
Appeal Tribunal gave Neill the go-ahead,

and the lawsuit was approved to go to trial.
"This is the first step in ensuring consumers

get back what they’re owed as a result 
of Sony breaking the law” said Neil

Sony was sued for £6.3 billion, roughly $7.9 
billion. If the lawsuit was won, that money

would be paid out to over 9 million players.
This is bad for Sony. The biggest pushback

against Neill’s lawsuit is that this is common 
industry practice. But maybe that’s a practice

that needs to change. In fact, Neill’s 
lawsuit has already created a ripple effect.

Valve, the owner of steam, has been called out for 
the same abuse as Sony. Valve takes 30% from all

Steam purchases, meaning costs get passed down to 
customers, just like on PlayStation. Now, Valve is

being sued, for £656 million. It’s possible many 
more lawsuits just like these two begin to pop up,

changing the video game industry as a whole.
The lawsuit against Sony could take years to

resolve. However this entire controversy shows us 
something interesting about Sony. They’ve begun

changing their entire business model, and have 
begun pouring billions into something massive.

Chapter 2: Digital Ownership
Setup

In 2023, PlayStation users 
received a strange email.

“As of 31 December 2023, due to our content 
licensing arrangements with content providers,

you will no longer be able to watch 
any of your previously purchased

Discovery content and the content will be 
removed from your video library,” (source)

These were hundreds of shows from the Discovery 
channel, shows which users had paid for.

There was no apology, no reason, and Sony was 
sure to say “We sincerely thank you for your

continued support.” This was unbelievable. 
Customers believed they owned these forever.

These were some extremely popular shows 
too, including the iconic MythBusters.

People were justifiably furious.
(Show tweet over narration:

https://x.com/DoesItPlay1/status/1730677804151292231)
It’s suspected that Sony’s

licenses and rights had expired.
Yet, due to immense backlash from customers,

it was forced to re-negotiate for the rights to 
Discovery shows. Fans received word the shows

they purchased would stay. But unfortunately, 
this isn’t the first time Sony’s done something

like this.
Tension

In 2017, Sony acquired a platform called 
Funimation, paying $143 million for 95%. Up

until now, Funimation sold DVDs of popular anime, 
including Dragon Ball Z and One Piece. They soon

began offering a streaming service, but many users 
used it as a digital library. The DVDs they bought

also came with a code, which gave customers the 
show in their library, forever. If you didn’t want

DVDs, you could also just buy the show digitally. 
Funimation was the perfect platform for anime. You

could stream new anime, but most importantly, you 
had a permanent library of your favorite shows.

Funimation was very upfront about this too. 
They said that you owned this “forever”...

In 2021, Sony also acquired 
Funimation’s competitor:

Crunchyroll. They planned to merge the two into 
a major anime platform, and this made Funimation

users nervous. What would happen to their 
libraries? They soon received their answer.

In March, 2022, Sony announced the two 
platforms would be merged. Content would be

migrated to Crunchyroll, along with users.
In an FAQ about the merger, they stated:

Please note that Crunchyroll does not 
currently support Funimation Digital copies,

which means that access to previously available 
digital copies will not be available. It was

official. The shows users bought, which they were 
promised they owned “forever”, would be gone.

Funimation was scheduled to shut down in April 
2024. But unlike the Discovery controversy,

there was no happy ending.
(Show tweets over narration:

https://x.com/EposVox/status/1755325269294850473
https://x.com/_cckirby/status/1755314705562816984)

Users were naturally, devastated, and furious. 
At Sony, but also at the new digital landscape

everything has moved into.
To add salt to the wound,

Crunchyroll also announced a price 
increase. From $55 a year, to $99.

How does something like this happen? Don’t 
you own what you buy? Well, for digital media,

the truth is a bit unsettling.
Resolution / Payoff

In the digital world, you don’t own anything. 
Even content you purchase. Companies carefully

word their terms and conditions to state this, 
that you instead buy a “license” to the content.

This affects more than just movies or TV. Video 
games have had this issue for many years. The

biggest platform “Steam” was just forced to 
change it’s messaging thanks to a new law,

explicitly telling customers they 
are purchasing a “license”. Other

publishers like Ubisoft have faced similar 
controversy, for pulling games customers

purchased from their libraries.
(Show tweet over below narration:

https://x.com/TreyTrey37/status/1755333171820827087
As a consequence, many users have turned back

to piracy. Viewing it as a necessity, 
and even a moral good compared to what

conglomerates like Sony are doing.
Others have turned back to physical

media. DVDs, Vinyl's, and physical copies, 
to ensure they always “own” the product.

It’s possible new regulations is needed, 
as a lot of this is still rather new.

Legislation may need to come in to protect 
customers, who despite purchasing a product,

are still at the whim of giant companies.
So why has Sony been doing all this?

Well, as it turns out, all of these cases aren’t 
isolated incidents. A recent announcement of

Sony’s puts this all into perspective.
Chapter 3: Sony’s Strategy

Setup
Sony has

been changing its strategy. The company 
has been planning something massive.

In early 2022, Sony acquired Crunchyroll, but 
this is far from their only acquisition. In fact,

it’s just one of many.
Tension

(Show graph on this article)
In 2022 and 2023, they began to ramp

up their investments. In this period, along with 
Crunchyroll, they acquired Bungie, the company

behind Destiny, who originally created Halo, 
Pixomondo, a visual effects company, who worked

on Game of Thrones, The Fast & Furious Franchise, 
and The Mandalorian, just to name a few.

These investments are worth billions, and 
they seem disconnected. But they’re actually

part of something much bigger. What is Sony 
building? Well, their 2024 strategy meeting

shows us exactly what.
Resolution / Payoff

Here, they revealed what they call 
the  “Creative Entertainment Vision”.

Sony detailed that in 2021, they organized their 
entertainment businesses: music, games, and

pictures, into a group architecture. The reason? 
More integration between them. They can push

their different IPs, be it anime, music, or video 
games, across their many platforms. (Show page 5)

And it paid off.
They also revealed that

these “three entertainment businesses, accounted 
for approximately 60% of the Group's consolidated

sales in FY2023” (source). (Show page 4)
Sony is now leaning even further into

entertainment, it plans to accelerate 
these “group synergies”, through their

“Creative Entertainment Vision”. 
This strategy has a lot of parts,

but the most important is that Sony plans 
to continue “maximizing the value” of

their IPs through a major new platform.
In section 6 of their strategy meeting,

Sony states it is “planning to develop 
an engagement platform for the Sony

Group by deploying core functions based on the 
network infrastructure of PlayStation Network,

which has established a robust network service”
That’s a lot of corporate speak, but it seems

like their strategy is creating a single 
entertainment platform. Connecting all

their services: PlayStation, Crunchyroll, 
Sony Music, Sony pictures, and much more.

They plan for customers to have one “user ID” 
across all these areas, and “integrated payments”.

This sounds like much more than a new Disney+ or 
Netflix. It sounds like something much bigger as

it spans multiple genres of 
entertainment from shows and

movies to video games, anime, and music. 
This cross-entertainment strategy also

extends into their individual IPs, with plans 
to turn video game franchises into TV shows.

(Show: 23:19 - 23:42)
Sony states it has the

hope of this platform being “widely adopted 
across the entertainment industry as a common

platform specialized for fan engagement”.
The question is, what does this look like

for customers?
Grand Payoff

There are a few ways this strategy could 
impact consumers. With Sony conglomerating

all kinds of media into one source, they 
will have all the power, as monopolies do.

It will certainly give Sony more control and 
leverage, meaning better licenses, and less cases

of TV shows disappearing. But as we’ve seen in 
the past, it very likely could mean the opposite.

They will set the terms and the price. In 
situations like these, it usually means high

prices, and bad terms for users. We might see Sony 
push things even further. Higher commissions from

third parties, meaning higher prices for games 
and movies. They also might pull content more

frequently, as they have more control.
While Sony is building for the future,

their tactics have undermined 
consumer trust in the present.

It’s hard to say exactly what this platform 
will look like, but with Sony’s track record,

only time will tell.
